For a volume charge density œÅ \rho œÅ, the electric field at r \mathbf{r} r is given by

E ( r ) = 1 4 œÄ œµ o ‚à´ ‘â ^ ‘â 2 œÅ ( r ‚Ä≤ ) ‚Äâ d œÑ ‚Ä≤ \mathbf{E}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\int\frac{\hat{\textbf{\char"0509}}}{\char"0509^2}\rho(\mathbf{r}')\thinspace d\tau' E(r)=4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´‘â2‘â^‚ÄãœÅ(r‚Ä≤)dœÑ‚Ä≤

  1. For a point charge Q Q Q at the origin, œÅ ( r ) = Q Œ¥ ( x ) Œ¥ ( y ) Œ¥ ( z ) \rho(\mathbf{r})=Q\delta(x)\delta(y)\delta(z) œÅ(r)=QŒ¥(x)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z). Evaluate the above integral using cartesian coordinates and unit vectors and this œÅ \rho œÅ.

  2. For a point charge Q Q Q at r ‚Ä≤ \mathbf{r}' r‚Ä≤, œÅ ( r ) = Q Œ¥ ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) Œ¥ ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) Œ¥ ( z ‚àí z ‚Ä≤ ) \rho(\mathbf{r})=Q\delta(x-x')\delta(y-y')\delta(z-z') œÅ(r)=QŒ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)Œ¥(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)Œ¥(z‚àíz‚Ä≤). Solution

1.

E ( r ) = 1 4 œÄ œµ o ‚à´ ‚à´ ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) x ^ + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) y ^ ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) 2 + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) 2 3 Q Œ¥ ( x ‚Ä≤ ) Œ¥ ( y ‚Ä≤ ) ‚Äâ d x ‚Ä≤ d y ‚Ä≤ = Q 4 œÄ œµ o ‚à´ Œ¥ ( y ‚Ä≤ ) d y ‚Ä≤ ‚à´ ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) x ^ + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) y ^ ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) 2 + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) 2 3 Œ¥ ( x ‚Ä≤ ) ‚Äâ d x ‚Ä≤ = Q 4 œÄ œµ o ‚à´ Œ¥ ( y ‚Ä≤ ) d y ‚Ä≤ ( x ‚àí 0 ) x ^ + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) y ^ ( x ‚àí 0 ) 2 + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) 2 3 = Q 4 œÄ œµ o ( x ‚àí 0 ) x ^ + ( y ‚àí 0 ) y ^ ( x ‚àí 0 ) 2 + ( y ‚àí 0 ) 2 3 = Q 4 œÄ œµ o x x ^ + y y ^ x 2 + y 2 3 \begin{align*}\mathbf{E}(\mathbf{r}) = & \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\int\int\frac{(x-x')\mathbf{\hat{x}}+(y-y')\mathbf{\hat{y}}}{\sqrt{(x-x')^2 + (y-y')^2}^3}Q\delta(x')\delta(y')\thinspace dx'dy' \\\\ = & \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\int\delta(y')dy'\int\frac{(x-x')\mathbf{\hat{x}}+(y-y')\mathbf{\hat{y}}}{\sqrt{(x-x')^2 + (y-y')^2}^3}\delta(x')\thinspace dx'\\\\ = & \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\int\delta(y')dy'\frac{(x-0)\mathbf{\hat{x}}+(y-y')\mathbf{\hat{y}}}{\sqrt{(x-0)^2 + (y-y')^2}^3}\\\\ = & \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\frac{(x-0)\mathbf{\hat{x}}+(y-0)\mathbf{\hat{y}}}{\sqrt{(x-0)^2 + (y-0)^2}^3}\\\\ = & \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\frac{x\mathbf{\hat{x}}+y\mathbf{\hat{y}}}{\sqrt{x^2 + y^2}^3} \end{align*} E(r)=====‚Äã4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´‚à´(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚ÄãQŒ¥(x‚Ä≤)Œ¥(y‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤dy‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã‚à´Œ¥(y‚Ä≤)dy‚Ä≤‚à´(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã‚à´Œ¥(y‚Ä≤)dy‚Ä≤(x‚àí0)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àí0)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚Äã4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã(x‚àí0)2+(y‚àí0)2‚Äã3(x‚àí0)x^+(y‚àí0)y^‚Äã‚Äã4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äãx2+y2‚Äã3xx^+yy^‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

The generalization to the 3-D problem given is straightforward.

2.

Here x ‚Ä≤ , y ‚Ä≤ x', y' x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤, and z ‚Ä≤ z' z‚Ä≤ are fixed points in space. Normally when given a charge density, we replace x , y , z x, y, z x,y,z with x ‚Ä≤ , y ‚Ä≤ , z ‚Ä≤ x',y',z' x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤,z‚Ä≤. To work around this issue, change the integration variables to be double primes. As before, in two dimensions,

In the integral above, the x ‚Ä≤ x' x‚Ä≤ is a constant with respect to integration (in the same way that in ‚à´ Œ¥ ( x ‚àí a ) d x \int\delta(x-a)dx ‚à´Œ¥(x‚àía)dx, a a a is a constant) and so we replace x ‚Ä≤ ‚Ä≤ x'' x‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ with this constant value.

E ( r ) = Q 4 œÄ œµ o ‚à´ Œ¥ ( y ‚Ä≤ ‚Ä≤ ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) d y ‚Ä≤ ‚Ä≤ ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) x ^ + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ‚Ä≤ ) y ^ ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) 2 + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ‚Ä≤ ) 2 3 = Q 4 œÄ œµ o ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) x ^ + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) y ^ ( x ‚àí x ‚Ä≤ ) 2 + ( y ‚àí y ‚Ä≤ ) 2 3 \begin{align*}\mathbf{E}(\mathbf{r}) = & \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\int\delta(y''-y')dy''\frac{(x-x')\mathbf{\hat{x}}+(y-y'')\mathbf{\hat{y}}}{\sqrt{(x-x')^2 + (y-y'')^2}^3}\\\\ =& \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\frac{(x-x')\mathbf{\hat{x}}+(y-y')\mathbf{\hat{y}}}{\sqrt{(x-x')^2 + (y-y')^2}^3} \end{align*} E(r)==‚Äã4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã‚à´Œ¥(y‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚àíy‚Ä≤)dy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚Äã4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

In class, I used an alternative approach where I replaced x ‚Ä≤ , y ‚Ä≤ , z ‚Ä≤ x',y',z' x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤,z‚Ä≤ with a x , a y , a z a_x, a_y, a_z ax‚Äã,ay‚Äã,az‚Äã and integrated over x ‚Ä≤ , y ‚Ä≤ , z ‚Ä≤ x',y',z' x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤,z‚Ä≤ so that I needed to evaluate

1.2 Delta Function I

  1. Suppose I = ‚à´ ‚àí 2 2 g ( x ) d x I = \int_{-2}^{2}g(x)dx I=‚à´‚àí22‚Äãg(x)dx. Find ‚à´ ‚àí 1 1 g ( 2 x ) d x \int_{-1}^{1}g(2x)dx ‚à´‚àí11‚Äãg(2x)dx and ‚à´ ‚àí 1 1 g ( ‚àí 2 x ) d x \int_{-1}^{1}g(-2x)dx ‚à´‚àí11‚Äãg(‚àí2x)dx in terms of I I I. Show graphically why the result makes sense using g ( x ) = x 2 g(x)=x^2 g(x)=x2.

  2. Show that ‚à´ Œ¥ ( b x ) f ( x ) d x = f ( 0 ) ‚à£ b ‚à£ \int \delta(bx)f(x)dx = \frac{f(0)}{|b|} ‚à´Œ¥(bx)f(x)dx=‚à£b‚à£f(0)‚Äã. (That is, show that Œ¥ ( b x ) = Œ¥ ( x ) / ‚à£ b ‚à£ \delta(bx)=\delta(x)/|b| Œ¥(bx)=Œ¥(x)/‚à£b‚à£).

Solution

1.

‚à´ ‚àí 1 1 g ( 2 x ) d x = ‚à´ ‚àí 1 1 g ( ‚àí 2 x ) d x = I / 2 \displaystyle \int_{-1}^{1}g(2x)dx=\int_{-1}^{1}g(-2x)dx=I/2 ‚à´‚àí11‚Äãg(2x)dx=‚à´‚àí11‚Äãg(‚àí2x)dx=I/2

2.

The generalization of the previous result is if I = ‚à´ ‚àí a b g ( x ) d x I = \int_{-a}^{b}g(x)dx I=‚à´‚àíab‚Äãg(x)dx, then for Œ± > 0 \alpha \gt 0 Œ±>0

‚à´ ‚àí a / Œ± b / Œ± g ( Œ± x ) d x = ‚à´ ‚àí a / Œ± b / Œ± g ( ‚àí Œ± x ) d x = I Œ± \displaystyle \int_{-a/\alpha}^{b/\alpha}g(\alpha x)dx=\int_{-a/\alpha}^{b/\alpha}g(-\alpha x)dx=\frac{I}{\alpha} ‚à´‚àía/Œ±b/Œ±‚Äãg(Œ±x)dx=‚à´‚àía/Œ±b/Œ±‚Äãg(‚àíŒ±x)dx=Œ±I‚Äã.

In the case that a = b = ‚àû a=b=\infty a=b=‚àû and a finite integral, it follows that ‚à´ g ( b x ) d x = ‚à´ g ( x ) ‚à£ b ‚à£ d x \int g(bx)dx=\int \frac{g(x)}{|b|}dx ‚à´g(bx)dx=‚à´‚à£b‚à£g(x)‚Äãdx, which applies to g ( x ) = Œ¥ ( x ) g(x)=\delta(x) g(x)=Œ¥(x) and thus whe have shown Œ¥ ( b x ) = Œ¥ ( x ) / ‚à£ b ‚à£ \delta(bx)=\delta(x)/|b| Œ¥(bx)=Œ¥(x)/‚à£b‚à£.

Griffiths 4th Edition example 1.15 gives an alternative solution. Another approach is to think of this as a transformation of variables problem in which the Jacobian, which involves the absolute value, is computed.

1.3 Delta Function II

  1. Find ‚à´ Œ¥ ( a + b x ) f ( x ) d x \int \delta(a + bx)f(x)dx ‚à´Œ¥(a+bx)f(x)dx using either

    1. identity 5. on page 26 of Jackson, 3rd Edition or

    2. using the substition u = a + b x u=a+bx u=a+bx.

  2. Prove identity 5. on Page 26 of Jackson 3rd edition

    Œ¥ ( f ( x ) ) = ‚àë i Œ¥ ( x ‚àí x i ) ‚à£ d f d x ( x i ) ‚à£ \displaystyle \delta(f(x))=\sum_i\frac{\delta(x-x_i)}{\left|\frac{df}{dx}(x_i)\right|} Œ¥(f(x))=i‚àë‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãdxdf‚Äã(xi‚Äã)‚à£‚à£‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚àíxi‚Äã)‚Äã

    where f ( x ) f(x) f(x) is assumed to have only simple zeros, located at x = x i x=x_i x=xi‚Äã. Do this by either

    1. explaing the omitted explanations in Dennery and Krzywicki 1967, page 237 or

    2. Taylor series expanding f ( x ) f(x) f(x) around the points x i x_i xi‚Äã where g ( x i ) = 0 g(x_i)=0 g(xi‚Äã)=0.

Solution

1.1 To avoid confusion with the f ( x ) f(x) f(x) in the given equation, re-write the identity as

Œ¥ ( g ( x ) ) = ‚àë i Œ¥ ( x ‚àí x i ) ‚à£ d g d x ( x i ) ‚à£ \displaystyle \delta(g(x))=\sum_i\frac{\delta(x-x_i)}{\left|\frac{dg}{dx}(x_i)\right|} Œ¥(g(x))=i‚àë‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãdxdg‚Äã(xi‚Äã)‚à£‚à£‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚àíxi‚Äã)‚Äã

Here g ( x ) = a + b x g(x)=a+bx g(x)=a+bx, which has a single zero at x 1 = ‚àí a / b x_1=-a/b x1‚Äã=‚àía/b. d g / d x = b dg/dx=b dg/dx=b, so

Œ¥ ( g ( x ) ) = Œ¥ ( x ‚àí x 1 ) ‚à£ d g d x ( x 1 ) ‚à£ = Œ¥ ( x ‚àí x 1 ) ‚à£ b ‚à£ = Œ¥ ( x + a / b ) ‚à£ b ‚à£ \displaystyle \delta(g(x))=\frac{\delta(x-x_1)}{|\frac{dg}{dx}(x_1)|}=\frac{\delta(x-x_1)}{|b|}=\frac{\delta(x+a/b)}{|b|} Œ¥(g(x))=‚à£dxdg‚Äã(x1‚Äã)‚à£Œ¥(x‚àíx1‚Äã)‚Äã=‚à£b‚à£Œ¥(x‚àíx1‚Äã)‚Äã=‚à£b‚à£Œ¥(x+a/b)‚Äã

and so

‚à´ Œ¥ ( a + b x ) f ( x ) d x = ‚à´ d x Œ¥ ( x + a / b ) ‚à£ b ‚à£ f ( x ) = f ( ‚àí a / b ) ‚à£ b ‚à£ \displaystyle \int \delta(a + bx)f(x)dx=\int dx \frac{\delta(x+a/b)}{|b|} f(x)=\frac{f(-a/b)}{|b|} ‚à´Œ¥(a+bx)f(x)dx=‚à´dx‚à£b‚à£Œ¥(x+a/b)‚Äãf(x)=‚à£b‚à£f(‚àía/b)‚Äã

1.2 With the substitution,

‚à´ Œ¥ ( u ) f ( ( u ‚àí b ) / a ) b d u = f ( ‚àí b / a ) b \displaystyle \int \delta(u)\frac{f((u-b)/a)}{b}du=\frac{f(-b/a)}{b} ‚à´Œ¥(u)bf((u‚àíb)/a)‚Äãdu=bf(‚àíb/a)‚Äã

for positive b b b and f ( ‚àí b / a ) / ( ‚àí b ) f(-b/a)/(-b) f(‚àíb/a)/(‚àíb) for negative b b b, so the integral is f ( ‚àí b / a ) / ‚à£ b ‚à£ f(-b/a)/|b| f(‚àíb/a)/‚à£b‚à£ as before.

1.4 Divergence Theorem

  1. Find the electric field E \mathbf{E} E due to a non-conducting sphere with a uniform volume charge density œÅ o \rho_o œÅo‚Äã and radius b b b that is centered on the origin.

  2. Show by direct calculation that

    ‚àÆ S E ‚ãÖ d a = ‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}\boldsymbol{\cdot} d\mathbf{a} = \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x ‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖda=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

    when the volume of integration V \mathcal{V} V is a sphere centered on the origin with

    1. radius b / 2 b/2 b/2

    2. radius 2 b 2b 2b

Solution

As mentioned in class, this is somewhat of a simple problem but was given to motivate the use of the Dirac delta function. What I said in class is briefly summarized at the end.

1. The electric field is

E ( r ‚â§ b ) = œÅ o 3 œµ o r ‚Äâ r ^ = q 4 œÄ œµ o r b 3 r ^ \mathbf{E}(r \le b) = \frac{\rho_o}{3\epsilon_o}r\thinspace \mathbf{\hat{r}}=\frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\frac{r}{b^3}\mathbf{\hat{r}} E(r‚â§b)=3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãrr^=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãb3r‚Äãr^

E ( r ‚â• b ) = œÅ o 3 œµ o b 3 r 2 ‚Äâ r ^ = q 4 œÄ œµ o 1 r 2 r ^ \mathbf{E}(r \ge b) = \frac{\rho_o}{3\epsilon_o}\frac{b^3}{r^2}\thinspace \mathbf{\hat{r}}=\frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\frac{1}{r^2}\mathbf{\hat{r}} E(r‚â•b)=3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãr2b3‚Äãr^=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãr21‚Äãr^

where q = œÅ o ‚Äâ 4 œÄ b 3 / 3 q=\rho_o\thinspace 4\pi b^3/3 q=œÅo‚Äã4œÄb3/3 was used.

2.

In the following,

A . ‚àá ‚ãÖ ( f ( r ) ‚Äâ r ^ ) = 1 r 2 ‚àÇ ‚àÇ r ( r 2 f ( r ) ) A.\qquad\boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot (f(r)\thinspace \hat{\mathbf{r}})=\frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^2f(r)\right) A.‚àá‚ãÖ(f(r)r^)=r21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(r2f(r))

is used. This follows from the identity for the divergence in spherical coordinates.

For r ‚â§ b r\le b r‚â§b and S \mathcal{S} S a spherical surface of radius r r r:

‚àÆ S E ( r ‚â§ b ) ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a = ‚à´ 0 2 œÄ ‚à´ 0 œÄ ( œÅ o 3 œµ o r ‚Äâ r ^ ) ‚ãÖ r ^ ‚Äâ r 2 sin ‚Å° Œ∏ ‚Äâ d Œ∏ ‚Äâ d œï = œÅ o œµ o 4 œÄ r 3 3 = q œµ o \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}(r\le b)\boldsymbol{\cdot} \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da = \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^\pi\left(\frac{\rho_o}{3\epsilon_o}r\thinspace \hat{\mathbf{r}}\right)\boldsymbol{\cdot}\hat{\mathbf{r}}\thinspace r^2\sin\theta\thinspace d\theta\thinspace d\phi=\frac{\rho_o}{\epsilon_o}\frac{4\pi r^3}{3}=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o} ‚àÆS‚ÄãE(r‚â§b)‚ãÖn^da=‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚Äã(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãrr^)‚ãÖr^r2sinŒ∏dŒ∏dœï=œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã34œÄr3‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

The divergence of E \mathbf{E} E is, using A . A. A.,

‚àá ‚ãÖ E ( r ‚â§ b ) = ‚àá ‚ãÖ ( œÅ o 3 œµ o r ‚Äâ r ^ ) = 1 r 2 ‚àÇ ‚àÇ r ( r 2 ( œÅ o 3 œµ o r ) ) = œÅ o œµ o \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}(r\le b)= \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \left(\frac{\rho_o}{3\epsilon_o}r\thinspace \hat{\mathbf{r}}\right) = \frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^2\left(\frac{\rho_o}{3\epsilon_o}r\right)\right)= \frac{\rho_o}{\epsilon_o} ‚àá‚ãÖE(r‚â§b)=‚àá‚ãÖ(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãrr^)=r21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(r2(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãr))=œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã

as expected from Gauss‚Äô law in differential form ( ‚àá ‚ãÖ E = œÅ / œµ o \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}=\rho/\epsilon_o ‚àá‚ãÖE=œÅ/œµo‚Äã with œÅ = œÅ o \rho=\rho_o œÅ=œÅo‚Äã). Therefore, for r ‚â§ b r\le b r‚â§b:

‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V œÅ o œµ o ‚Äâ d 3 x = œÅ o œµ o 4 œÄ r 3 3 = q œµ o \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x=\int_{\mathcal{V}} \frac{\rho_o}{\epsilon_o}\thinspace d^3x=\frac{\rho_o}{\epsilon_o}\frac{4\pi r^3}{3}=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o} ‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´V‚Äãœµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãd3x=œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã34œÄr3‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

‚àÆ S E ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a = ‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da = \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x ‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

For r > b r\gt b r>b and S \mathcal{S} S a spherical surface of radius r r r:

‚àÆ S E ( r ‚â• b ) ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a = ‚à´ 0 2 œÄ ‚à´ 0 œÄ ( œÅ o 3 œµ o b 3 r 2 ‚Äâ r ^ ) ‚ãÖ r ^ ‚Äâ r 2 sin ‚Å° Œ∏ ‚Äâ d Œ∏ ‚Äâ d œï = ‚à´ 0 2 œÄ ‚à´ 0 œÄ ( œÅ o 3 œµ o b 3 ) sin ‚Å° Œ∏ ‚Äâ d Œ∏ ‚Äâ d œï = œÅ o œµ o 4 œÄ b 3 3 = q œµ o \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}(r\ge b)\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da = \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^\pi\left(\frac{\rho_o}{3\epsilon_o}\frac{b^3}{r^2}\thinspace \hat{\mathbf{r}}\right)\cdot\hat{\mathbf{r}}\thinspace r^2\sin\theta\thinspace d\theta\thinspace d\phi = \int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^\pi\left(\frac{\rho_o}{3\epsilon_o}b^3\right)\sin\theta\thinspace d\theta\thinspace d\phi=\frac{\rho_o}{\epsilon_o}\frac{4\pi b^3}{3}=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o} ‚àÆS‚ÄãE(r‚â•b)‚ãÖn^da=‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚Äã(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãr2b3‚Äãr^)‚ãÖr^r2sinŒ∏dŒ∏dœï=‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚Äã(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãb3)sinŒ∏dŒ∏dœï=œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã34œÄb3‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

The divergence is

‚àá ‚ãÖ E ( r ‚â• b ) = œÅ o b 3 3 œµ o ‚àá ‚ãÖ r ^ r 2 = 1 r 2 ‚àÇ ‚àÇ r ( r 2 ( œÅ o b 3 3 œµ o 1 r 2 ) ) = œÅ o b 3 3 œµ o 1 r 2 ‚àÇ ‚àÇ r ( 1 ) = 0 \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}(r\ge b)=\frac{\rho_o b^3}{3\epsilon_o} \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}}{r^2} = \frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^2\left(\frac{\rho_o b^3}{3\epsilon_o}\frac{1}{r^2}\right)\right)=\frac{\rho_o b^3}{3\epsilon_o}\frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(1\right)=0 ‚àá‚ãÖE(r‚â•b)=3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äãb3‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã=r21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(r2(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äãb3‚Äãr21‚Äã))=3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äãb3‚Äãr21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(1)=0

also as expected from Gauss‚Äô law in differential form ( ‚àá ‚ãÖ E = œÅ / œµ o \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}=\rho/\epsilon_o ‚àá‚ãÖE=œÅ/œµo‚Äã with œÅ = 0 \rho=0 œÅ=0). Important: the last equality in the above equation is only true when r ‚â† 0 r\ne 0 rÓÄ†=0; when r = 0 r=0 r=0, the result is 0 / 0 0/0 0/0. This issue is considered later in this solution.

One must split the volume integral into two integrals, one for r ‚â§ b r\le b r‚â§b and the other for r > b r\gt b r>b to account for the divergence being different in the two regions. As shown earlier, in the region r > b r\gt b r>b, the divergence is zero.

‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ( r ‚â§ b ) ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ V r ‚â• b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ( r ‚â• b ) ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b œÅ o œµ o ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ V r ‚â• b 0 ‚Äâ d 3 x = œÅ o œµ o 4 œÄ b 3 3 + 0 = q œµ o \begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x& = & \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}(r\le b)\thinspace d^3x & + & \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\ge b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}(r\ge b)\thinspace d^3x\\\\ & = & \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} \frac{\rho_o}{\epsilon_o}\thinspace d^3x & + & \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\ge b}}}0\thinspace d^3x\\\\ & = & \frac{\rho_o}{\epsilon_o}\frac{4\pi b^3}{3} & + & 0\\\\ & = & \frac{q}{\epsilon_o} \end{array} ‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x‚Äã====‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖE(r‚â§b)d3x‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãœµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãd3xœµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã34œÄb3‚Äãœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â•b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖE(r‚â•b)d3x‚à´Vr‚â•b‚Äã‚Äã0d3x0‚Äã

Conclusion: for r > b r\gt b r>b,

‚àÆ S E ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a = ‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da = \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x ‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

Motivation for this problem

I gave this problem as a lead-in/follow-up for my discussion of the motivation for the delta function. For a point charge, the integrand of

‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E p ‚Äâ d 3 x \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}_p\thinspace d^3x ‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x

with

E p = q 4 œÄ œµ o r ^ r 2 \mathbf{E}_p=\frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}}{r^2} Ep‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãr2r^‚Äã

is zero everywhere except at the origin ( r = 0 r=0 r=0) where it is indeterminate in the form of 0 / 0 0/0 0/0 because

‚àá ‚ãÖ E p = q 4 œÄ œµ o ‚àá ‚ãÖ r ^ r 2 = q 4 œÄ œµ o 1 r 2 ‚àÇ ‚àÇ r ( 1 ) = { 0 / 0 if  r = 0 0 if  r ‚â† 0 \displaystyle \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}_p = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_o} \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}}{r^2} = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(1\right) = \begin{cases} 0/0 & \text{if }r = 0 \\ 0 & \text{if }r\ne 0 \end{cases} ‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãr21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(1)={0/00‚Äãif r=0if rÓÄ†=0‚Äã

However,

‚àÆ S E p ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a = q œµ o \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}_p\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da =\frac{q}{\epsilon_o} ‚àÆS‚ÄãEp‚Äã‚ãÖn^da=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

does not have an indeterminacy. Therefore, the divergence theorem

‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚àó p ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚àÆ ‚àó S E p ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}*p\thinspace d^3x=\oint*{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}_p\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da ‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖE‚àópd3x=‚àÆ‚àóSEp‚Äã‚ãÖn^da

applied to E \mathbf{E} E for a point charge gives

indeterminate integral = q œµ o \text{indeterminate integral}=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o} indeterminate integral=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

In this problem, it has been shown that if a point charge q q q is modeled as having a uniform density for r ‚â§ b r\le b r‚â§b and having zero density for r > b r\gt b r>b, then the indeterminacy problem can be avoided and

‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚àÆ S E ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x = \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da ‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da

for all r r r and for arbitrarily small (but non-zero) b b b (but see also ‚Äòother notes‚Äô below). That is, the divergence theorem gives the correct answer for a solid ball of charge that is arbitrarily small but not zero.

Although the divergence theorem does not apply for E p \mathbf{E}_p Ep‚Äã, to avoid having to think about a solid ball with arbitrarily small but non zero radius is to use it with the convention that

‚àá ‚ãÖ E p = q 4 œÄ œµ o ‚àá ‚ãÖ r ^ r 2 = q œµ o Œ¥ ( r ) \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}_p=\frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}}{r^2}=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\delta(\mathbf{\mathbf{r}}) ‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r)

where the function Œ¥ ( r ) \delta(\mathbf{\mathbf{r}}) Œ¥(r) is zero everywhere except at r = 0 \mathbf{r}=\mathbf{0} r=0 and integrates to 1 when the volume of integration includes r = 0 \mathbf{r}=\mathbf{0} r=0.

‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V q 4 œÄ œµ o ‚àá ‚ãÖ r ^ r 2 ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V q œµ o Œ¥ ( r ) ‚Äâ d 3 x = q œµ o \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x=\int_{\mathcal{V}}\frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_o}\boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}}{r^2}\thinspace d^3x=\int_{\mathcal{V}}\frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\delta(\mathbf{\mathbf{r}})\thinspace d^3x=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o} ‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´V‚Äã4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äãd3x=‚à´V‚Äãœµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r)d3x=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

That is,

‚àá ‚ãÖ r ^ r 2 = 4 œÄ Œ¥ ( r ) \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}}{r^2}=4\pi\delta(\mathbf{\mathbf{r}}) ‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã=4œÄŒ¥(r)

When you see the delta function used in an integration, you should think back to this problem and realize that the delta function is being used instead of modeling the electric field as a point charge q q q as having a uniform density for r < b r\lt b r<b and zero density for r > b r\gt b r>b.

Griffiths takes a different approach to motivating the introduction of the delta function. He notes that the indeterminate integral of the divergence

‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E p ‚Äâ d 3 x = indeterminate integral \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}_p\thinspace d^3x=\text{indeterminate integral} ‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x=indeterminate integral

must be equal to q / œµ o q/\epsilon_o q/œµo‚Äã because of the divergence theorem (which technically does not apply because of the singularity in E \mathbf{E} E at r = 0 r=0 r=0):

‚àÆ S E p ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a = q œµ o ‚áí ‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E p ‚Äâ d 3 x = q œµ o \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}_p\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da = \frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\quad\Rightarrow\quad\int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}_p\thinspace d^3x=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o} ‚àÆS‚ÄãEp‚Äã‚ãÖn^da=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚áí‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

He then notes that r ^ / r 2 \hat{\mathbf{r}}/r^2 r^/r2 has the property that its divergence

‚àá ‚ãÖ r ^ r 2 \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot\frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}}{r^2} ‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã

  1. is zero everywhere except at the origin (where it is interminate)

  2. integrates to a constant ( 4 œÄ 4\pi 4œÄ) over any volume V \mathcal{V} V that includes r = 0 r=0 r=0 (based on the assumption that the divergence theorem applies and resolves the indeterminacy)

That is, although

‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E p ‚Äâ d 3 x \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}_p\thinspace d^3x ‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x

has an indeterminate integrand at r = 0 r=0 r=0, the divergence theorem must be true, and so this integral must be equal to the surface integral, which is q œµ o \frac{q}{\epsilon_o} œµo‚Äãq‚Äã. Therefore,

‚àá ‚ãÖ E p = q œµ o Œ¥ ( r ) \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}_p=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\delta(\mathbf{\mathbf{r}}) ‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r)

where the function Œ¥ ( r ) \delta(\mathbf{r}) Œ¥(r) is defined to be zero unless r = 0 r=0 r=0 and integrates over a volume that includes r = 0 \mathbf{r}=\mathbf{0} r=0 to 1. This explanation is somewhat awkward because it asserts that the divergence theorem must be correct even though the field E p \mathbf{E}_p Ep‚Äã does not satisfy the requirements for the divergence theorem to apply. (The requirements for the divergence theorem to apply are that the components of the vector field and their derivatives are continuous.)

In summary, the integral

‚à´ V f ( r ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x \int_{\mathcal{V}} f(\mathbf{r})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x ‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

is indeterminant when E ‚àº r ^ / r 2 \mathbf{E}\sim \hat{\mathbf{r}}/r^2 E‚àºr^/r2 and V \mathcal{V} V includes r = 0 r=0 r=0. If we model a point charge as having a uniform density for r ‚â§ b r\le b r‚â§b, and zero density for r > b r\gt b r>b, where b ‚â† 0 b\ne 0 bÓÄ†=0 is smaller than any length scale in the problem, the indeterminacy is removed. Instead of two integrations, one for r ‚â§ b r \le b r‚â§b and the other for r > b r\gt b r>b, we can simply replace ‚àá ‚ãÖ E p \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}_p ‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äã with ( q / œµ o ) Œ¥ ( r ) (q/\epsilon_o)\delta(\mathbf{\mathbf{r}}) (q/œµo‚Äã)Œ¥(r); the result of any integration will be the same.

A second motivation for using the delta function is that we often want to do an integral of the form

‚à´ V f ( r ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E p ‚Äâ d 3 x \int_{\mathcal{V}} f(\mathbf{r})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}_p\thinspace d^3x ‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x

(Recall that f ( r ) f(\mathbf{r}) f(r) means f ( x , y , z ) f(x,y,z) f(x,y,z)). As before, integral is indeterminate because ‚àá ‚ãÖ ( r ^ / r 2 ) \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot (\hat{\mathbf{r}}/r^2) ‚àá‚ãÖ(r^/r2) is 0/0 at r = 0 r=0 r=0. To work around this problem, we can again model the point charge as having a uniform density for r ‚â§ b r\le b r‚â§b and zero density for r > b r\gt b r>b. Then

‚à´ V f ( r ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b f ( r ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E b ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ V r > b f ( r ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E b ‚Äâ d 3 x \int_{\mathcal{V}} f(\mathbf{r})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x=\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} f(\mathbf{r})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}_b\thinspace d^3x+\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\gt b}}} f(\mathbf{r})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}_b\thinspace d^3x ‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEb‚Äãd3x+‚à´Vr>b‚Äã‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEb‚Äãd3x

The second integral is identically zero because ‚àá ‚ãÖ E b = 0 \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot\mathbf{E}_b=0 ‚àá‚ãÖEb‚Äã=0 for r > b r\gt b r>b. If f ( r ) f(\mathbf{r}) f(r) can be expanded as a Taylor series

f ( r ) ‚âÉ f ( 0 ) + r ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá f ‚Äâ ] r = 0 ; + ; ‚Ä¶ f(\mathbf{r})\simeq f(\mathbf{0}) + \mathbf{r}\cdot\left[\boldsymbol{\nabla}f\thinspace \right]_{\mathbf{r}=0};+;‚Ä¶ f(r)‚âÉf(0)+r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã;+;‚Ä¶

then

‚à´ V r ‚â§ b f ( r ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ( f ( 0 ) + r ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá f ‚Äâ ] r = 0 ‚ÄÖ‚Ää + ‚ÄÖ‚Ää ‚Ä¶ ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b f ( 0 ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ( r ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá f ‚Äâ ] r = 0 ‚ÄÖ‚Ää + ‚ÄÖ‚Ää ‚Ä¶ ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = f ( 0 ) ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ( r ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá f ‚Äâ ] r = 0 ‚ÄÖ‚Ää + ‚ÄÖ‚Ää ‚Ä¶ ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = q œµ o f ( 0 ) ‚ÄÖ‚Ää + ‚ÄÖ‚Ää q œµ o ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ( r ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá f ‚Äâ ] r = 0 ‚ÄÖ‚Ää + ‚ÄÖ‚Ää ‚Ä¶ ) d 3 x \begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} f(\mathbf{r})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x & = & \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} \left(f(\mathbf{0})+\mathbf{r}\cdot\left[\boldsymbol{\nabla}f\thinspace \right]_{\mathbf{r}=0}\thickspace+\thickspace ‚Ä¶\right)\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x\\ & = & \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} f(\mathbf{0})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x+\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} (\mathbf{r}\cdot\left[\boldsymbol{\nabla}f\thinspace \right]_{\mathbf{r}=0}\thickspace+\thickspace‚Ä¶)\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x\\ & = & f(\mathbf{0})\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x+\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} \frac{q}{\epsilon_o}f(\mathbf{0})\thickspace+\thickspace\frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} \left(\mathbf{r}\cdot\left[\boldsymbol{\nabla}f\thinspace \right]_{\mathbf{r}=0}\thickspace+\thickspace ‚Ä¶\right)d^3x\\ \end{array} ‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x‚Äã====‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã(f(0)+r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã+‚Ä¶)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãf(0)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x+‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã(r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã+‚Ä¶)‚àá‚ãÖEd3xf(0)‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x+‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã(r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã+‚Ä¶)‚àá‚ãÖEd3xœµo‚Äãq‚Äãf(0)+œµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã(r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã+‚Ä¶)d3x‚Äã

The second and higher-order terms in the last equation approach zero as b ‚Üí 0 b\rightarrow 0 b‚Üí0. To see this, note that for small enough b b b,

q œµ o ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b f ( r ) ‚Äâ d 3 x ‚Üí 4 œÄ 3 b 3 < f ( 0 ) > \frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} f(\mathbf{r})\thinspace d^3x\rightarrow \frac{4\pi}{3}b^3\left<f(\mathbf{0})\right> œµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãf(r)d3x‚Üí34œÄ‚Äãb3‚ü®f(0)‚ü©

where the < > \left<\right> ‚ü®‚ü© is the average in V \mathcal{V} V in a sphere of radius b b b. Therefore,

q œµ o ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b r ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá f ‚Äâ ] r = 0 ‚Äâ d 3 x ‚Üí b ‚Üí 0 q œµ o 4 œÄ 3 b 3 < r ‚ãÖ [ ‚àá f ‚Äâ ] r = 0 > ‚Üí b ‚Üí 0 0 \frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V_{r\le b}}} \mathbf{r}\cdot\left[\boldsymbol{\nabla}f\thinspace \right]_{\mathbf{r}=0}\thinspace d^3x\xrightarrow[b\rightarrow 0]{} \frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\frac{4\pi}{3}b^3\left<\mathbf{r}\cdot\left[\boldsymbol{\nabla}f\thinspace \right]_{\mathbf{r}=0}\right>\xrightarrow[b\rightarrow 0]{} 0 œµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãr‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äãd3xb‚Üí0‚Äãœµo‚Äãq‚Äã34œÄ‚Äãb3‚ü®r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã‚ü©b‚Üí0‚Äã0

The same argument applies to the higher-order terms in the Taylor series expansion.

Prior to the introduction of the delta function by Dirac in the 1930s, the above argument was used when an integral of the form

‚à´ V f ( r ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V}} f(\mathbf{r})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x ‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

was encountered and E \mathbf{E} E was that for a point charge and V \mathcal{V} V that included the location of the point charge.

With the introduction of the Dirac delta, one can simply use ‚àá ‚ãÖ E = q œµ o Œ¥ ( r ) \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{E}=\frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\delta(\mathbf{\mathbf{r}}) ‚àá‚ãÖE=œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r) to get the same result without needing to think about the above steps:

‚à´ V f ( r ) ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V f ( r ) q œµ o Œ¥ ( r ) ‚Äâ d 3 x = { f ( 0 ) q œµ o if  V  includes  r = 0 0 otherwise \displaystyle \int_{\mathcal{V}} f(\mathbf{r})\boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x = \int_{\mathcal{V}} f(\mathbf{r})\frac{q}{\epsilon_o}\delta(\mathbf{\mathbf{r}})\thinspace d^3x = \begin{cases} f(\mathbf{0})\frac{q}{\epsilon_o} & \text{if }\mathcal{V}\text{ includes } r = 0 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} ‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´V‚Äãf(r)œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r)d3x={f(0)œµo‚Äãq‚Äã0‚Äãif V includes r=0otherwise‚Äã

That is, using the delta function for the divergence of E \mathbf{E} E due to a point charge will give us the same answer as if we had modeled the point charge as having a uniform density for r ‚â§ b r\le b r‚â§b, zero density for r > b r\gt b r>b, Taylor series expanded f ( r ) f(\mathbf{r}) f(r), and then let b ‚Üí 0 b\rightarrow 0 b‚Üí0.

Other notes

In the above, I showed that the divergence theorem gave the correct result for E \mathbf{E} E and any r r r by direct calculation. However, the divergence theorem

‚àÆ S E ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a = ‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x \oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da = \int_{\mathcal{V}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x ‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

requires that within V \mathcal{V} V, the components of E \mathbf{E} E and their derivatives are continuous. In E \mathbf{E} E, E r E_r Er‚Äã is continuous, but ‚àÇ E r / ‚àÇ r \partial E_r/\partial r ‚àÇEr‚Äã/‚àÇr is not. So it appears that direct calculation for r > b r\gt b r>b gave a result that was consistent with the divergence theorem even though the assumptions required to apply the divergence theorem are not satisfied. To see why this occurred, use the divergence theorem in the two parts of V \mathcal{V} V where the divergence theorem applies for E \mathbf{E} E.

First, consider the application of the divergence theorem for the volume between r = 0 r=0 r=0 and r = b r=b r=b.

‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ S r = b E ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a \int_{\mathcal{V_{r \le b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x = \int_\mathcal{S_{r=b}} \mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da ‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Sr=b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da

The outward normal to S r = b \mathcal{S_{r=b}} Sr=b‚Äã for V r ‚â§ b \mathcal{V_{r \le b}} Vr‚â§b‚Äã is + r ^ +\hat{\mathbf{r}} +r^, so

I . ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ S r = b E ‚ãÖ r ^ ‚Äâ d a I.\quad \int_{\mathcal{V_{r \le b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x =\int_\mathcal{S_{r=b}} \mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{r}}\thinspace da I.‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Sr=b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖr^da

Next, consider the application of the divergence theorem for the volume between r = b r=b r=b and r = 2 b r=2b r=2b (the result will apply to any r > b r\gt b r>b). In this case, there is an inner and outer surface and so the surface integral has two parts.

‚à´ V b ‚â§ r ‚â§ 2 b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚àÆ S r = b E ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a + ‚àÆ S r = 2 b E ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a \int_{\mathcal{V_{b \le r \le 2b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x= \oint_\mathcal{S_{r=b}} \mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da + \oint_\mathcal{S_{r=2b}} \mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da ‚à´Vb‚â§r‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚àÆSr=b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da+‚àÆSr=2b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da

The outward normal to S r = b \mathcal{S_{r=b}} Sr=b‚Äã for this volume is ‚àí r ^ -\hat{\mathbf{r}} ‚àír^ and the outward normal to S r = 2 b \mathcal{S_{r=2b}} Sr=2b‚Äã is + r ^ +\hat{\mathbf{r}} +r^, so

I I . ‚à´ V b ‚â§ r ‚â§ 2 b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚àí ‚àÆ S r = b E ‚ãÖ r ^ ‚Äâ d a + ‚àÆ S r = 2 b E ‚ãÖ r ^ ‚Äâ d a II.\quad \int_{\mathcal{V_{b \le r \le 2b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x=-\oint_\mathcal{S_{r=b}} \mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{r}}\thinspace da + \oint_\mathcal{S_{r=2b}} \mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{r}}\thinspace da II.‚à´Vb‚â§r‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚àí‚àÆSr=b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖr^da+‚àÆSr=2b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖr^da

Using I . I. I. and I I . II. II. with the volume integral expressed in two parts

‚à´ V r ‚â§ 2 b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ V r ‚â§ b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ V ‚Äâ b ‚â§ r ‚â§ 2 b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x \int_{\mathcal{V_{r \le 2b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x=\int_{\mathcal{V_{r \le b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x + \int_{\mathcal{V_{\thinspace b \le r \le 2b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x ‚à´Vr‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x+‚à´Vb‚â§r‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

gives

‚à´ V r ‚â§ 2 b ‚àá ‚ãÖ E ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ S r = 2 b E ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a \int_{\mathcal{V_{r \le 2b}}} \boldsymbol{\nabla} \cdot \mathbf{E}\thinspace d^3x = \int_{\mathcal{S_{r=2b}}}\mathbf{E}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da ‚à´Vr‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Sr=2b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da

(The surface integrals at r = b r=b r=b cancel because their normal directions are in opposite directions.)

2.1 Representing œÅ \rho œÅ Using Œ¥ \delta Œ¥ and Œò \Theta Œò

The step (or Heavyside step) function, Œò \Theta Œò, is defined by

Œò ( x ) = { 1 x > 0 0 x ‚â§ 0 \Theta(x) = \begin{cases} 1 & x > 0\\ 0 & x \le 0\end{cases} Œò(x)={10‚Äãx>0x‚â§0‚Äã

Œò \Theta Œò can be used to to express a charge density in a compact mathematical form. For example, instead of stating ‚Äúa uniformly charged sphere centered on the origin, with total charge Q Q Q, and radius b b b‚Äù, we can write œÅ ( x , y , z ) = Q ( 4 / 3 ) œÄ b 3 Œò ( b ‚àí r ) \rho(x,y,z)=\frac{Q}{(4/3)\pi b^3}\Theta(b-r) œÅ(x,y,z)=(4/3)œÄb3Q‚ÄãŒò(b‚àír). When this density is integrated over all space, the result is Q Q Q:

‚à´ œÅ ( x ) ‚Äâ d 3 x = Q ( 4 / 3 ) œÄ b 3 ‚à´ 0 2 œÄ d œï ‚à´ 0 œÄ sin ‚Å° Œ∏ d Œ∏ ‚à´ 0 ‚àû Œò ( b ‚àí r ) r 2 d r \displaystyle\int\rho(\mathbf{x})\thinspace d^3x=\frac{Q}{(4/3)\pi b^3}\int_{0}^{2\pi}d\phi\int_{0}^{\pi}\sin\theta d\theta\int_{0}^{\infty}\Theta(b-r)r^2dr ‚à´œÅ(x)d3x=(4/3)œÄb3Q‚Äã‚à´02œÄ‚Äãdœï‚à´0œÄ‚ÄãsinŒ∏dŒ∏‚à´0‚àû‚ÄãŒò(b‚àír)r2dr

Because Œò ( b ‚àí r ) = 0 \Theta(b-r)=0 Œò(b‚àír)=0 for r ‚â• b r\ge b r‚â•b and Œò ( b ‚àí r ) = 1 \Theta(b-r)=1 Œò(b‚àír)=1 for r < b r\lt b r<b, the limits on the r r r integral can be modfied and the Œò \Theta Œò function removed:

‚à´ œÅ ( x ) ‚Äâ d 3 x = Q ( 4 / 3 ) œÄ b 3 ‚à´ 0 2 œÄ d œï ‚à´ 0 œÄ sin ‚Å° Œ∏ d Œ∏ ‚à´ 0 b r 2 d r \displaystyle\int\rho(\mathbf{x})\thinspace d^3x=\frac{Q}{(4/3)\pi b^3}\int_{0}^{2\pi}d\phi\int_{0}^{\pi}\sin\theta d\theta\int_{0}^{b}r^2dr ‚à´œÅ(x)d3x=(4/3)œÄb3Q‚Äã‚à´02œÄ‚Äãdœï‚à´0œÄ‚ÄãsinŒ∏dŒ∏‚à´0b‚Äãr2dr

The integrals above evaluate to the volume of a sphere of radius b b b so that

‚à´ œÅ ( x ) ‚Äâ d 3 x = Q \displaystyle\int\rho(\mathbf{x})\thinspace d^3x=Q ‚à´œÅ(x)d3x=Q

  1. Write the piecewise function f ( x ) = { 1 ‚à£ x ‚à£ < b 0 ‚à£ x ‚à£ ‚â• b f(x) = \begin{cases} 1 & |x| \lt b\\ 0 & |x| \ge b\end{cases} f(x)={10‚Äã‚à£x‚à£<b‚à£x‚à£‚â•b‚Äã using one or more Œò \Theta Œò functions.

  2. Find the volume charge density œÅ \rho œÅ in cylindrical coordinates in terms of Œ¥ \delta Œ¥ and/or Œò \Theta Œò for an infinitely long cylinder of radius b b b with a charge density per unit length of Œª o \lambda_o Œªo‚Äã uniformly distributed on its surface. Assume that the cylinder‚Äôs centerline is along the z z z-axis.

  3. Repeat 2. assuming the cylinder is finite and extends from z = ‚àí h / 2 z=-h/2 z=‚àíh/2 to z = h / 2 z=h/2 z=h/2.

Solution

  1. As mentioned in class, an easy way to solve this is to write f ( x ) f(x) f(x) as the sum of two step functions. One shifted to the left by b b b, corresponding to Œò ( x + b ) \Theta(x+b) Œò(x+b); the other shifted to the right and inverted, corresponding to Œò ( x ‚àí b ) \Theta(x-b) Œò(x‚àíb). Thus,

    f ( x ) = Œò ( x + b ) ‚àí Œò ( x ‚àí b ) f(x) = \Theta(x+b) - \Theta(x-b) f(x)=Œò(x+b)‚àíŒò(x‚àíb).

    Other solutions:

    f ( x ) = Œò ( b ‚àí ‚à£ x ‚à£ ) f(x) = \Theta(b-|x|) f(x)=Œò(b‚àí‚à£x‚à£)

    f ( x ) = Œò ( b 2 ‚àí x 2 ) = Œò [ ( b ‚àí x ) ( b + x ) ] f(x)=\Theta(b^2-x^2)=\Theta[(b-x)(b+x)] f(x)=Œò(b2‚àíx2)=Œò[(b‚àíx)(b+x)]

    f ( x ) = Œò ( b + x ) ‚àí Œò ( x ‚àí b ) f(x) = \Theta(b+x) - \Theta(x-b) f(x)=Œò(b+x)‚àíŒò(x‚àíb)

    It may be interesting to use d Œò / d x = Œ¥ ( x ) d\Theta/dx=\delta(x) dŒò/dx=Œ¥(x) develop an identity for Œò ( f ( x ) ) \Theta(f(x)) Œò(f(x)) similar to identity 5. on page 26 of Jackson 4th Edition.

    Checks:

    • when x = 0 x=0 x=0, f ( x ) = Œò ( b ) ‚àí Œò ( ‚àí b ) = 1 ‚àí 0 = 1 f(x) = \Theta(b) - \Theta(-b) = 1-0 = 1 f(x)=Œò(b)‚àíŒò(‚àíb)=1‚àí0=1

    • when x = 2 b x=2b x=2b, f ( x ) = Œò ( 3 b ) ‚àí Œò ( b ) = 1 ‚àí 1 = 0 f(x) = \Theta(3b) - \Theta(b) = 1-1 = 0 f(x)=Œò(3b)‚àíŒò(b)=1‚àí1=0

    • when x = ‚àí 2 b x=-2b x=‚àí2b, f ( x ) = Œò ( ‚àí b ) ‚àí Œò ( ‚àí 3 b ) = 0 ‚àí 0 = 0 f(x) = \Theta(-b) - \Theta(-3b) = 0-0 = 0 f(x)=Œò(‚àíb)‚àíŒò(‚àí3b)=0‚àí0=0

  2. We want a charge distribution that is localized at a cylindrical radial distance b b b. œÅ ( s ) = C Œ¥ ( s ‚àí b ) \rho(s) = C\delta(s-b) œÅ(s)=CŒ¥(s‚àíb) has this feature, where C C C is a constant. We also need the integral of this charge density over all space to equal the total charge on the cylinder, which is Q = Œª o h Q=\lambda_o h Q=Œªo‚Äãh assuming that the length of the cylinder is h h h. Thus, we need to find C C C such that

    Q = Œª o h = ‚à´ œÅ ( x ) d 3 x \displaystyle Q=\lambda_o h = \int \rho(\mathbf{x})d^3x Q=Œªo‚Äãh=‚à´œÅ(x)d3x

    Q = Œª o h = ‚à´ ‚àí h / 2 h / 2 ‚à´ 0 2 œÄ ‚à´ 0 ‚àû C Œ¥ ( s ‚àí b ) s d s d œï d z \displaystyle Q=\lambda_o h = \int_{-h/2}^{h/2}\int_{0}^{2\pi}\int_{0}^\infty C\delta(s-b) sdsd\phi dz Q=Œªo‚Äãh=‚à´‚àíh/2h/2‚Äã‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0‚àû‚ÄãCŒ¥(s‚àíb)sdsdœïdz

    Q = Œª o h = 2 œÄ h C ‚à´ 0 ‚àû Œ¥ ( s ‚àí b ) s d s = 2 œÄ h C b ‚áí C = Œª o / 2 œÄ b \displaystyle Q=\lambda_o h = 2\pi hC\int_{0}^\infty \delta(s-b) sds=2\pi h C b \quad\Rightarrow\quad C=\lambda_o/2\pi b Q=Œªo‚Äãh=2œÄhC‚à´0‚àû‚ÄãŒ¥(s‚àíb)sds=2œÄhCb‚áíC=Œªo‚Äã/2œÄb

    and so

    œÅ ( x ) = Œª o 2 œÄ b Œ¥ ( s ‚àí b ) \displaystyle \rho(\mathbf{x}) = \frac{\lambda_o}{2\pi b}\delta(s-b) œÅ(x)=2œÄbŒªo‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(s‚àíb)

    Equivalently, we can write

    œÅ ( x ) = Œª o 2 œÄ s Œ¥ ( s ‚àí b ) \displaystyle \rho(\mathbf{x}) = \frac{\lambda_o}{2\pi s}\delta(s-b) œÅ(x)=2œÄsŒªo‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(s‚àíb)

    because Œ¥ ( s ‚àí b ) / s = Œ¥ ( s ‚àí b ) / b \delta(s-b)/s=\delta(s-b)/b Œ¥(s‚àíb)/s=Œ¥(s‚àíb)/b, which follows from the fact that the delta function is only non-zero at s = b s=b s=b.

  3. Here we apply the result from part 1. with the replacement of b b b in that problem with h / 2 h/2 h/2:

    œÅ ( x ) = Œª o 2 œÄ b Œ¥ ( s ‚àí b ) [ Œò ( x + h / 2 ) ‚àí Œò ( x ‚àí h / 2 ) ] \displaystyle \rho(\mathbf{x}) = \frac{\lambda_o}{2\pi b}\delta(s-b)[\Theta(x+h/2) - \Theta(x-h/2)] œÅ(x)=2œÄbŒªo‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(s‚àíb)[Œò(x+h/2)‚àíŒò(x‚àíh/2)]

2.2 Green‚Äôs Reciprocity Theorem

For discrete charges, Green‚Äôs Reciprocity Theorem for N N N charges is

‚àë i = 1 N Œ¶ i q i ‚Ä≤ = ‚àë i = 1 N Œ¶ i ‚Ä≤ q i \sum_{i=1}^{N}\Phi_i q'_i=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\Phi'_i q_i i=1‚àëN‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Äãqi‚Ä≤‚Äã=i=1‚àëN‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã

Consider charges q 1 , q 2 q_1,q_2 q1‚Äã,q2‚Äã, and q 3 q_3 q3‚Äã at locations x 1 , x 2 x_1,x_2 x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã, and x 3 x_3 x3‚Äã, respectively, on the x x x-axis. At these locations, the potentials are Œ¶ 1 , Œ¶ 2 , \Phi_1,\Phi_2, Œ¶1‚Äã,Œ¶2‚Äã, and Œ¶ 3 \Phi_3 Œ¶3‚Äã, respectively.

If a new system of charges q 1 ‚Ä≤ , q 2 ‚Ä≤ q'_1,q'_2 q1‚Ä≤‚Äã,q2‚Ä≤‚Äã, and q 3 ‚Ä≤ q'_3 q3‚Ä≤‚Äã is created by placing them at the same locations x 1 , x 2 x_1,x_2 x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã, and x 3 x_3 x3‚Äã, respectively, the potentials at these locations are Œ¶ 1 ‚Ä≤ , Œ¶ 2 ‚Ä≤ , \Phi'_1,\Phi'_2, Œ¶1‚Ä≤‚Äã,Œ¶2‚Ä≤‚Äã, and Œ¶ 3 ‚Ä≤ \Phi'_3 Œ¶3‚Ä≤‚Äã, respectively.

Show that

‚àë i = 1 3 Œ¶ i q i ‚Ä≤ = ‚àë i = 1 3 Œ¶ i ‚Ä≤ q i \sum_{i=1}^{3}\Phi_i q'_i=\sum_{i=1}^{3}\Phi'_i q_i i=1‚àë3‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Äãqi‚Ä≤‚Äã=i=1‚àë3‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã

Solution

The physical interpretation of Green‚Äôs Reciprocity theorem is that the work required to put charges an unprimed set of charges at x 1 , x 2 , x 3 x_1,x_2,x_3 x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,x3‚Äã under the influence of only the electric field of a primed set of charges x 1 , x 2 , x 3 x_1,x_2,x_3 x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,x3‚Äã must be the same as the work required to put a primed set of charges at x 1 , x 2 , x 3 x_1,x_2,x_3 x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,x3‚Äã under the influence of only the electric field of an unprimed set of charges at x 1 , x 2 , x 3 x_1,x_2,x_3 x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,x3‚Äã.

Using

Œ¶ i = ‚àë j = 1 j ‚â† i N q j ‚à£ x j ‚àí x i ‚à£ = ‚àë j = 1 j ‚â† i N q j d j i \displaystyle\Phi_i=\sum_{\substack{j=1\\j\ne i}}^N \frac{q_j}{|x_j-x_i|}=\sum_{\substack{j=1\\j\ne i}}^N \frac{q_j}{d_{ji}} Œ¶i‚Äã=j=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äã‚à£xj‚Äã‚àíxi‚Äã‚à£qj‚Äã‚Äã=j=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdji‚Äãqj‚Äã‚Äã

gives, for N = 3 N=3 N=3, the left-hand side terms in ‚àë i = 1 3 Œ¶ i q i ‚Ä≤ = ‚àë i = 1 3 Œ¶ i ‚Ä≤ q i \sum_{i=1}^{3}\Phi_i q'_i=\sum_{i=1}^{3}\Phi'_i q_i ‚àëi=13‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Äãqi‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àëi=13‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã

Œ¶ 1 q 1 ‚Ä≤ = 0 + q 2 q 1 ‚Ä≤ d 21 + q 3 q 1 ‚Ä≤ d 31 Œ¶ 2 q 2 ‚Ä≤ = q 1 q 2 ‚Ä≤ d 12 + 0 + q 3 q 2 ‚Ä≤ d 32 Œ¶ 3 q 3 ‚Ä≤ = q 1 q 3 ‚Ä≤ d 13 + q 2 q 3 ‚Ä≤ d 23 + 0 \begin{array}{rc} \Phi_1q'_1 & = & 0 & + & \frac{q_2q'_1}{d_{21}} & + & \frac{q_3q'_1}{d_{31}} \\ \\ \Phi_2q'_2 & = & \frac{q_1q'_2}{d_{12}} & + & 0 & + & \frac{q_3q'_2}{d_{32}} \\ \\ \Phi_3q'_3 & = & \frac{q_1q'_3}{d_{13}} & + & \frac{q_2q'_3}{d_{23}} & + & 0 & \end{array} Œ¶1‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶2‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶3‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã===‚Äã0d12‚Äãq1‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äãd13‚Äãq1‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äãd21‚Äãq2‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã0d23‚Äãq2‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äãd31‚Äãq3‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äãd32‚Äãq3‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã0‚Äã‚Äã

The right-hand side terms in ‚àë i = 1 3 Œ¶ i q i ‚Ä≤ = ‚àë i = 1 3 Œ¶ i ‚Ä≤ q i \sum_{i=1}^{3}\Phi_i q'_i=\sum_{i=1}^{3}\Phi'_i q_i ‚àëi=13‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Äãqi‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àëi=13‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã can be expanded as

Œ¶ 1 ‚Ä≤ q 1 = 0 + q 2 ‚Ä≤ q 1 d 21 + q 3 ‚Ä≤ q 1 d 31 Œ¶ 2 ‚Ä≤ q 2 = q 1 ‚Ä≤ q 2 d 12 + 0 + q 2 q 3 ‚Ä≤ d 32 Œ¶ 3 ‚Ä≤ q 3 = q 1 ‚Ä≤ q 3 d 13 + q 2 ‚Ä≤ q 3 d 23 + 0 \begin{array}{rc} \Phi'_1q_1 & = & 0 & + & \frac{q'_2q_1}{d_{21}} & + & \frac{q'_3q_1}{d_{31}} \\ \\ \Phi'_2q_2 & = & \frac{q'_1q_2}{d_{12}} & + & 0 & + & \frac{q_2q'_3}{d_{32}} \\ \\ \Phi'_3q_3 & = & \frac{q'_1q_3}{d_{13}} & + & \frac{q'_2q_3}{d_{23}} & + & 0 & \end{array} Œ¶1‚Ä≤‚Äãq1‚ÄãŒ¶2‚Ä≤‚Äãq2‚ÄãŒ¶3‚Ä≤‚Äãq3‚Äã‚Äã===‚Äã0d12‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚Äãq2‚Äã‚Äãd13‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚Äãq3‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äãd21‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚Äãq1‚Äã‚Äã0d23‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚Äãq3‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äãd31‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äãq1‚Äã‚Äãd32‚Äãq2‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã0‚Äã‚Äã

In the above, the left‚Äì and right‚Äìhand sides of the equation to prove were written in the form of a matrix. In this form, one can see that the matrices are transposes of each other. If we sum all elements in a matrix, the result is the same if we sum all elements of that matrix transposed.

More generally, one can use

‚àë i = 1 N q i Œ¶ i ‚Ä≤ = ‚àë i = 1 N q i ‚àë j = 1 j ‚â† i N q j ‚Ä≤ d i j = ‚àë i = 1 N ‚àë j = 1 j ‚â† i N q j ‚Ä≤ q i d i j \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{N} q_i\Phi'_i = \sum_{i=1}^{N} q_i \sum_{\substack{j=1\\j\ne i}}^N \frac{q'_j}{d_{ij}}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\sum_{\substack{j=1\\j\ne i}}^N \frac{ q'_j q_i}{d_{ij}} i=1‚àëN‚Äãqi‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äã=i=1‚àëN‚Äãqi‚Äãj=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã=i=1‚àëN‚Äãj=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã

Repeating with the primed and unprimed swapped and starting with a dummy index of j j j instead of i i i, we have

‚àë j = 1 N q j ‚Ä≤ Œ¶ j = ‚àë j = 1 N q j ‚Ä≤ ‚àë i = 1 i ‚â† j N q i d j i = ‚àë j = 1 N ‚àë i = 1 i ‚â† j N q j ‚Ä≤ q i d i j \displaystyle \sum_{j=1}^{N} q'_j\Phi_j = \sum_{j=1}^{N} q'_j \sum_{\substack{i=1\\i\ne j}}^N \frac{q_i}{d_{ji}}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\sum_{\substack{i=1\\i\ne j}}^N \frac{ q'_j q_i}{d_{ij}} j=1‚àëN‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶j‚Äã=j=1‚àëN‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãi=1iÓÄ†=j‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdji‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã=j=1‚àëN‚Äãi=1iÓÄ†=j‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã

Where in the last step, d j i = d i j d_{ji}=d_{ij} dji‚Äã=dij‚Äã was used.

One can think of q j ‚Ä≤ q i / d i j q'_j q_i/d_{ij} qj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã/dij‚Äã as elements in a matrix. The equations

‚àë i = 1 N ‚àë j = 1 j ‚â† i N q j ‚Ä≤ q i d i j \displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{N}\sum_{\substack{j=1\\j\ne i}}^N \frac{ q'_j q_i}{d_{ij}} i=1‚àëN‚Äãj=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã and ‚àë j = 1 N ‚àë i = 1 i ‚â† j N q j ‚Ä≤ q i d i j \displaystyle \sum_{j=1}^{N}\sum_{\substack{i=1\\i\ne j}}^N \frac{ q'_j q_i}{d_{ij}} j=1‚àëN‚Äãi=1iÓÄ†=j‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã

both result in the sum of all elements of a matrix excluding the diagonals. The only difference is the order in which the elements of the matrix are summed. For a continuous charge distribution, we would use the fact that the order of integration could be changed to arrive at the result ‚à´ d q Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ ( x ) d 3 x = ‚à´ d q ‚Ä≤ Œ¶ ( x ‚Ä≤ ) d 3 x ‚Ä≤ \int dq \Phi'(x) d^3x = \int dq' \Phi(x') d^3x' ‚à´dqŒ¶‚Ä≤(x)d3x=‚à´dq‚Ä≤Œ¶(x‚Ä≤)d3x‚Ä≤.

2.3 Green‚Äôs Reciprocity Use

  1. In class, I partially did problem 1.13 of Jackson 3rd Edition (I only found the net charge on the upper of the plate). Find the net charge on the lower plate. Justify your steps at the level of detail given in class. (I stated an easy way of finding the net charge induced on the lower plate, but I want you to do it the long way, which requires steps similar to the ones used in class.)

  2. A point charge at a distance r r r from the origin is between two grounded spherical conducting shells of radius b b b and c c c that are centered on the origin. Find the net charge induced on the surfaces at b b b and c c c.

For discussion during the next class: In my solution to part 1., I used the continous form of reciprocity. Could I have solved it using the discrete form?

Solution

1.

Let the unprimed system have a conducting plate in z = 0 z=0 z=0 plane held at Œ¶ = 0 \Phi=0 Œ¶=0 and a conducting plate in the z = d z=d z=d plane held at at Œ¶ = V o \Phi=V_o Œ¶=Vo‚Äã.

Let the unprimed system have a conducting plate in the z = 0 z=0 z=0 plane held at at Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ = 0 \Phi'=0 Œ¶‚Ä≤=0, a conducting plate in the z = d z=d z=d plane held at Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ = 0 \Phi'=0 Œ¶‚Ä≤=0, and a point charge q ‚Ä≤ q' q‚Ä≤ at ( x , y , z ) = ( x o , 0 , 0 ) (x,y,z)=(x_o,0,0) (x,y,z)=(xo‚Äã,0,0).

One can use the equation from problem 1.11 of Jackson or start with

‚à´ a l l ‚Äâ s p a c e œÅ ‚Ä≤ Œ¶ ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚à´ a l l ‚Äâ s p a c e œÅ Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ ‚Äâ d 3 x \displaystyle\int_{all\thinspace space}\rho'\Phi\thinspace d^3x = \int_{all\thinspace space}\rho\Phi'\thinspace d^3x ‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅ‚Ä≤Œ¶d3x=‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅŒ¶‚Ä≤d3x

and split the charge density into surface and volume charge densities œÉ \sigma œÉ and œÅ v \rho_v œÅv‚Äã, where the subscript v v v means charge not on the conducting surfaces S \mathcal{S} S:

‚à´ a l l ‚Äâ s p a c e œÅ v ‚Ä≤ Œ¶ ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ S œÉ ‚Ä≤ Œ¶ ‚Äâ d a = ‚à´ a l l ‚Äâ s p a c e œÅ v Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ S œÉ Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ ‚Äâ d a \displaystyle\int_{all\thinspace space}\rho_v'\Phi\thinspace d^3x+\int_{\mathcal{S}}\sigma'\Phi\thinspace da = \int_{all\thinspace space }\rho_v\Phi'\thinspace d^3x+\int_{\mathcal{S}}\sigma\Phi'\thinspace da ‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅv‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶d3x+‚à´S‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤Œ¶da=‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅv‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤d3x+‚à´S‚ÄãœÉŒ¶‚Ä≤da

The first term on RHS is zero because œÅ v = 0 \rho_v=0 œÅv‚Äã=0 (there are no charges in the unprimed system between the plates). The second term on the RHS is zero becuase Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ = 0 \Phi'=0 Œ¶‚Ä≤=0 on conducting surfaces.

The first term on the LHS reduces to q ‚Ä≤ Œ¶ ( x o ) q'\Phi(x_o) q‚Ä≤Œ¶(xo‚Äã) becuase œÅ v ‚Ä≤ = q ‚Ä≤ Œ¥ ( x ‚àí x o ) Œ¥ ( y ) Œ¥ ( z ) \rho_v'=q'\delta(x-x_o)\delta(y)\delta(z) œÅv‚Ä≤‚Äã=q‚Ä≤Œ¥(x‚àíxo‚Äã)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z) (the notation œÅ v ‚Ä≤ = q ‚Ä≤ Œ¥ ( x ‚àí x o ‚Ä≤ ) \rho_v'=q'\delta(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x_o}') œÅv‚Ä≤‚Äã=q‚Ä≤Œ¥(x‚àíxo‚Äã‚Ä≤) is also acceptable; this gives Œ¶ ( x o ) \Phi(\mathbf{x_o}) Œ¶(xo‚Äã), which is the same things as Œ¶ ( x o ) \Phi(x_o) Œ¶(xo‚Äã) notationally). The potential between the plates in the unprimed system is

Œ¶ ( x ) = V o x d \displaystyle\Phi(x)=V_o\frac{x}{d} Œ¶(x)=Vo‚Äãdx‚Äã

and so the first term on the LHS is q ‚Ä≤ V o x o / d q'V_ox_o/d q‚Ä≤Vo‚Äãxo‚Äã/d.

The second term on LHS is composed of integrals over the top and bottom surfaces (assuming all of the charges in the primed system are on the plates or at x o x_o xo‚Äã; this is discussed below). Given that Œ¶ = 0 \Phi=0 Œ¶=0 on bottom surface, we are left with an integral over upper surface ( u u u) for which Œ¶ = V o \Phi=V_o Œ¶=Vo‚Äã.

‚à´ ‚Äâ u œÉ ‚Ä≤ V o ‚Äâ d a = V o ‚à´ ‚Äâ u œÉ ‚Ä≤ ‚Äâ d a = V o q u ‚Ä≤ \int_{\mathcal\thinspace u}\sigma'V_o\thinspace da=V_o\int_{\mathcal\thinspace u}\sigma'\thinspace da=V_oq'_u ‚à´u‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤Vo‚Äãda=Vo‚Äã‚à´u‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤da=Vo‚Äãqu‚Ä≤‚Äã

The equation

‚à´ a l l ‚Äâ s p a c e œÅ v ‚Ä≤ Œ¶ ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ S œÉ ‚Ä≤ Œ¶ ‚Äâ d a = ‚à´ a l l ‚Äâ s p a c e œÅ v Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚à´ S œÉ Œ¶ ‚Ä≤ ‚Äâ d a \displaystyle\int_{all\thinspace space}\rho_v'\Phi\thinspace d^3x+\int_{\mathcal{S}}\sigma'\Phi\thinspace da = \int_{all\thinspace space }\rho_v\Phi'\thinspace d^3x+\int_{\mathcal{S}}\sigma\Phi'\thinspace da ‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅv‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶d3x+‚à´S‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤Œ¶da=‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅv‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤d3x+‚à´S‚ÄãœÉŒ¶‚Ä≤da

thus reduces to

q ‚Ä≤ V o x o / d + V o q u ‚Ä≤ = 0 ‚áí q u ‚Ä≤ = ‚àí q x o d \displaystyle q'V_ox_o/d + V_oq'_u = 0 \Rightarrow \boxed{q'_u=-q\frac{x_o}{d}} q‚Ä≤Vo‚Äãxo‚Äã/d+Vo‚Äãqu‚Ä≤‚Äã=0‚áíqu‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àíqdxo‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

One can reverse the potentials on the unprimed system to arrive at the charge q l ‚Ä≤ q'_l ql‚Ä≤‚Äã on the lower primed surface, which is

q l ‚Ä≤ = q ‚Ä≤ ( x o d ‚àí 1 ) \boxed{q'_l=q'\left(\frac{x_o}{d}-1\right)} ql‚Ä≤‚Äã=q‚Ä≤(dxo‚Äã‚Äã‚àí1)‚Äã

Note also that the assumption that the total charge in the universe is zero

q u ‚Ä≤ + q l ‚Ä≤ + q = 0 q'_u+q'_l+q=0 qu‚Ä≤‚Äã+ql‚Ä≤‚Äã+q=0

could have also been used to find q l ‚Ä≤ q'_l ql‚Ä≤‚Äã given q u ‚Ä≤ q'_u qu‚Ä≤‚Äã.

Note: In the solution, I assumed all free charges were on the upper and lower surfaces and there were no charges on far-away surfaces; this statement is justified post hoc by uniqueness and because computing q u ‚Ä≤ q'_u qu‚Ä≤‚Äã and q l ‚Ä≤ q'_l ql‚Ä≤‚Äã in this way gave q u ‚Ä≤ + q l ‚Ä≤ + q = 0 q'_u+q'_l+q=0 qu‚Ä≤‚Äã+ql‚Ä≤‚Äã+q=0. To avoid this assumption, one would need to use equation 1.35 of Jackson with the volume being the volume between the plates. Curiously, in problem 1.11, Jackson suggests using equation 1.35 to come up with what he calls Green‚Äôs reciprocation theorem, seemingly so it could be applied in problem 1.12. However, the equation in problem 1.11 does not directly apply because the surface of the volume between the plates is not all conductor (only the top and bottom parts of the volume are conductors, the sides of this volume are not). One is left with having to use equation 1.35 and the argument that because the problem is 1-dimensional, the derivatives of the potential with respect to the normal on the side surfaces of the volume are zero.

2.

The procedure here is nearly identical to part 1. The potential between the sphere in the unprimed system when the potential at r = b r=b r=b is V o V_o Vo‚Äã and the potential at r = c r=c r=c is zero is

Œ¶ ( r ) = V o b c ‚àí b ( c r ‚àí 1 ) \displaystyle\Phi(r)=V_o\frac{b}{c-b}\left(\frac{c}{r}-1\right) Œ¶(r)=Vo‚Äãc‚àíbb‚Äã(rc‚Äã‚àí1)

which can be found by solving the boundary value problem

Œ¶ ( c ) = 0 Œ¶ ( b ) = V o \Phi(c)=0\quad \Phi(b)=V_o Œ¶(c)=0Œ¶(b)=Vo‚Äã

‚àá 2 Œ¶ = 1 r 2 d 2 ( r 2 Œ¶ ) d r 2 = 0 ‚áí Œ¶ = A + B / r \displaystyle\nabla^2\Phi = \frac{1}{r^2}\frac{d^2 (r^2\Phi)}{dr^2}= 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \Phi = A + B/r ‚àá2Œ¶=r21‚Äãdr2d2(r2Œ¶)‚Äã=0‚áíŒ¶=A+B/r

to find A A A and B B B or by assuming a charge Q Q Q on the outer sphere and ‚àí Q -Q ‚àíQ on the inner sphere and using Gauss‚Äô law to find E r E_r Er‚Äã and then V ( c ) ‚àí V ( b ) = ‚àí ‚à´ b c E r ‚Äâ d r V(c)-V(b)=-\int_b^cE_r\thinspace dr V(c)‚àíV(b)=‚àí‚à´bc‚ÄãEr‚Äãdr (the Q Q Q will cancel). The final result is

q r = b ‚Ä≤ = ‚àí V o q ‚Ä≤ b c ‚àí b ( c r o ‚àí 1 ) \displaystyle q'_{r=b}=-V_o\frac{q'b}{c-b}\left(\frac{c}{r_o}-1\right) qr=b‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àíVo‚Äãc‚àíbq‚Ä≤b‚Äã(ro‚Äãc‚Äã‚àí1)

q r = c ‚Ä≤ = + V o q ‚Ä≤ c c ‚àí b ( b r o ‚àí 1 ) \displaystyle q'_{r=c}=+V_o\frac{q'c}{c-b}\left(\frac{b}{r_o}-1\right) qr=c‚Ä≤‚Äã=+Vo‚Äãc‚àíbq‚Ä≤c‚Äã(ro‚Äãb‚Äã‚àí1)

2.4 Green‚Äôs Identity Derivation

In one of the steps required to derive his identities (discussed in 1.8 of Jackson, 3rd Edition), Green said: ‚ÄúConsider the divergence of a scalar function f f f multiplied by a vector function A \mathbf{A} A‚Äù.

  1. Show that

‚àá ‚ãÖ ( f A ) = f ‚Äâ ‚àá ‚ãÖ A + A ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá f ) \mathbf{\nabla}\boldsymbol{\cdot} (f\mathbf{A}) = f\thinspace \mathbf{\nabla}\boldsymbol{\cdot} \mathbf{A} + \mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\cdot}(\mathbf{\nabla}f) ‚àá‚ãÖ(fA)=f‚àá‚ãÖA+A‚ãÖ(‚àáf)

  1. Show that

    ‚à´ V f ‚Äâ ‚àá ‚ãÖ A ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚àí ‚à´ V A ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá f ) ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚àÆ S f A ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a \int_{\mathcal{V}} f\thinspace\mathbf{\nabla}\boldsymbol{\cdot} \mathbf{A}\thinspace d^3x = -\int_{\mathcal{V}}\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\cdot}(\mathbf{\nabla}f)\thinspace d^3x+\oint_{\mathcal{S}} f\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\cdot}\hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da ‚à´V‚Äãf‚àá‚ãÖAd3x=‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãA‚ãÖ(‚àáf)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãfA‚ãÖn^da

    where V \mathcal{V} V is the volume enclosed by the surface S \mathcal{S} S, n ^ \hat{\mathbf{n}} n^ is the normal to a differential area element d a da da on S \mathcal{S} S, and d 3 x d^3x d3x is a differential volume element.

  2. Verify the result in 2. by using an f f f, A \mathbf{A} A and V \mathcal{V} V of your choosing.

Solution

1. This can be shown by writing ‚àá \boldsymbol{\nabla} ‚àá and A \mathbf{A} A in cartesian coordinates.

2. The divergence theorem

‚àÆ S U ‚ãÖ d a = ‚à´ V ‚àá ‚ãÖ U ‚Äâ d 3 x \displaystyle\oint_{\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{U}\cdot d\mathbf{a}=\int_{\mathcal{V}}\boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{U}\thinspace d^3x ‚àÆS‚ÄãU‚ãÖda=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖUd3x

using U = f A \mathbf{U}=f\mathbf{A} U=fA on the LHS and U = f ( ‚àá ‚ãÖ A ) + A ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá f ) \mathbf{U}=f(\mathbf{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{A}) + \mathbf{A}\cdot(\mathbf{\nabla}f) U=f(‚àá‚ãÖA)+A‚ãÖ(‚àáf) the the RHS gives

‚àÆ S f A ‚ãÖ d a = ‚à´ V [ ‚àá ‚ãÖ f ( ‚àá ‚ãÖ A ) + A ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá f ) ] ‚Äâ d 3 x \displaystyle\oint_{\mathcal{S}}f\mathbf{A}\cdot d\mathbf{a}=\int_{\mathcal{V}}\Big[\boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot f(\mathbf{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{A}) + \mathbf{A}\cdot(\mathbf{\nabla}f)\big]\thinspace d^3x ‚àÆS‚ÄãfA‚ãÖda=‚à´V‚Äã[‚àá‚ãÖf(‚àá‚ãÖA)+A‚ãÖ(‚àáf)]d3x

and rearrangement gives

‚à´ V f ( ‚àá ‚ãÖ A ) ‚Äâ d 3 x = ‚àí ‚à´ V A ‚ãÖ ( ‚àá f ) ‚Äâ d 3 x + ‚àÆ S f A ‚ãÖ n ^ ‚Äâ d a \displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{V}} f(\mathbf{\nabla}\cdot \mathbf{A})\thinspace d^3x = -\int_{\mathcal{V}}\mathbf{A}\cdot(\mathbf{\nabla}f)\thinspace d^3x+\oint_{\mathcal{S}} f\mathbf{A}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{n}}\thinspace da ‚à´V‚Äãf(‚àá‚ãÖA)d3x=‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãA‚ãÖ(‚àáf)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãfA‚ãÖn^da

Note that when A = A x ( x ) x ^ \mathbf{A}=A_x(x)\hat{\mathbf{x}} A=Ax‚Äã(x)x^, f = f ( x ) f=f(x) f=f(x), and V \mathcal{V} V is a cube, this reduces to the integration by parts formula.
